qas.question: When hydrogen oxidates, what is it removing?
When hydrogen oxidates, what does it end up giving?
What theory suggests that acids are proton donors?

context: Oxidation of hydrogen removes its electron and gives <a1_0>H+<a1_0/>, which contains no <a0_0>electrons<a0_0/> and a nucleus which is usually composed of one proton. That is why H+ is often called a proton. This species is central to discussion of acids. Under the <a2_0>Bronsted-Lowry<a2_0/> theory, acids are proton donors, while bases are proton acceptors.
